title: 108_hr2539
content:
The "Violence Against Children Act of 2003" may be cited as the short title for this legislation. Congress finds that children under 18 make up a significant portion of crime victims, with high rates of sex crimes and kidnapping. Adolescents aged 12-17 are more likely to be victims of violent crime than adults. Only 28% of crimes against children are reported, leading to serious consequences such as abuse-related deaths and long-term negative effects on development and mental health. Child abuse has long-lasting negative effects on children and families, including delayed development, depression, substance abuse, and increased likelihood of experiencing or perpetrating domestic violence as an adult. Most local agencies lack resources to protect children and families adequately. Failure to pay child support is a form of neglect, leading to children living in poverty and suffering from inadequate education, healthcare, and housing. TITLE I--ENHANCED FEDERAL ROLE IN CRIMES AGAINST CHILDREN

SEC. 101. ENHANCED PENALTIES. Chapter 110 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include a new section on violence against children. It specifies penalties for injuring or attempting to injure a person under 18 years of age, including imprisonment for up to 10 years and fines. Harsher penalties apply if the offense results in death, involves kidnapping, aggravated sexual abuse, or attempted murder. The new section on violence against children in Chapter 110 of title 18, United States Code, specifies penalties for offenses involving kidnapping, aggravated sexual abuse, or attempted murder. The circumstances include the offense occurring during travel across state lines or using interstate commerce, or the use of firearms or other weapons that have traveled in interstate commerce. The new section in Chapter 110 of title 18, United States Code, specifies penalties for offenses involving violence against children, including kidnapping, aggravated sexual abuse, or attempted murder. The penalties apply if the offense involves interstate or foreign commerce and the use of firearms or other weapons that have traveled in interstate commerce. The United States Sentencing Commission will enhance penalties for federal crimes against children under 18. The Comptroller General will review state laws on crimes against children and report findings to Congress within 6 months of the Act's enactment. SEC. 102. Enhanced assistance for criminal investigations and prosecutions by state and local law enforcement officials. The Attorney General provides assistance in criminal investigations or prosecutions of violent crimes against minors at the request of State, tribal, or local governments. Priority is given to cases involving offenders who have committed crimes in multiple states or rural jurisdictions with limited resources. The Attorney General prioritizes requests for assistance in criminal investigations involving offenders who have committed crimes in multiple states or rural jurisdictions with limited resources. TITLE II--GRANT PROGRAMS

SEC. 201. FEDERAL ASSISTANCE TO STATE AND LOCAL LAW ENFORCEMENT. The Attorney General awards grants to assist in developing and strengthening effective law enforcement and prosecution of crimes against children, providing personnel, training, technical assistance, data collection, and equipment for apprehension and adjudication of offenders. This includes training law enforcement officers, prosecutors, judges, and court personnel, developing specialized units targeting crimes against children, and implementing more effective police strategies. The Attorney General awards grants to enhance law enforcement and prosecution of crimes against children by developing specialized units, implementing effective police strategies, and promoting cross-collaboration between law enforcement and child services. This includes training, data collection systems, and communication networks to track arrests and convictions for crimes against children. The Attorney General awards grants to enhance law enforcement and prosecution of crimes against children by developing specialized units, implementing effective police strategies, promoting cross-collaboration between law enforcement and child services, and addressing the needs of Indian tribes in dealing with crimes against children through programs. States, Indian tribal governments, or local governments seeking grants must submit applications meeting specified requirements. To apply for a grant under this section, a State, Indian tribal government, or local government must submit an application to the Attorney General with required information. The application must describe the need for the grant, how the funds will be used, and the expected outcomes. Additionally, the applicant must show consultation in developing a plan to implement the grant. To apply for a grant under this section, the State, Indian tribal government, or local government must consult with nonprofit victim services programs and certify that federal funds will supplement non-federal funds for activities funded under this section. Authorization of Appropriations: $25,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2004 to 2008 to carry out activities funded under this section, provided that the State, Indian tribal government, or local government is in compliance with sections 301 and 302. SEC. 202. EDUCATION, PREVENTION, AND VICTIMS' ASSISTANCE GRANTS. The Attorney General awards grants to assist in providing education, prevention, intervention, and victims' assistance services for crimes against children, including seminars, hotlines, training programs, and awareness efforts. The Attorney General awards grants for various services related to crimes against children, including informational materials, intervention services, awareness efforts, emergency medical treatment, counseling, and increasing mental health professionals specializing in victims of crimes against children. Applicants must submit an application for the grant. Each entity seeking a grant for services related to crimes against children must submit an application to the Attorney General, detailing the need, intended use, and expected outcomes of the grant funds. The application for a grant related to crimes against children must detail the need, intended use, and expected outcomes of the grant funds. Additionally, the plan to implement the grant must demonstrate consultation and coordination with victim services programs experienced in helping child crime victims. The grant application must show experience in providing services to child crime victims, including education, prevention, and intervention. Federal funds should supplement, not replace, non-Federal funds for funded activities. The grant application must demonstrate experience in serving child crime victims, with Federal funds supplementing non-Federal funds for activities. The Attorney General may waive the requirement for nongovernmental organizations in exceptional circumstances, and compliance with section 303 is necessary for the State or organization operating the funded activities. The nongovernmental organization must operate funded activities in compliance with section 303. $25,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2004 to 2008. SEC. 301 requires each State receiving grants to establish a statewide AMBER Alert network for child abduction cases within 3 years. SEC. 302 mandates the use of the National Incident-Based Reporting System for statistical gathering. SEC. 303 pertains to the National Safe Haven program. Each State receiving grants must have a statute allowing parents to leave newborns with hospital staff anonymously, collect family medical history, search missing person databases, and publicize the Safe Haven law within 3 years of this Act. The State must search missing person databases after a child is relinquished and publicize the Safe Haven law. An exception allows a State to deny anonymity if a newborn shows signs of abuse. SEC. 304. IMPROVED CHILD PROTECTION SERVICES PROGRAMS. Each State receiving child welfare services funding must submit a report on their program within 180 days. The General Accounting Office will report to Congress on State practices and policies regarding child welfare programs. This includes how States maintain records and verify the well-being of children under their care. The report required under subpart 1 of part B of title IV of the Social Security Act must address how States are maintaining records and verifying the well-being of children in their care, the impact of the review system by the Secretary of Health and Human Services on state reforms, best practices implemented by States, and recommendations for legislative changes by Congress. The Senate suggests extending tax treatment to child support nonpayment by allowing recipients to deduct unpaid amounts from their taxes and requiring non-paying parents to add the unpaid amount to their income for tax purposes.
